entry.title: From Korus to Preonus: The Story Behind Our Name
entry.summary: Discover why we renamed our framework from Korus to Preonus, and the meaning behind the new name rooted in particle physics and Latin.
entry.content:
Today, I'm excited to share the story of our framework's evolution‚Äînot just in code, but in identity. What began as Korus has transformed into Preonus, a name that better reflects our mission and philosophy.

Why the Change?‚Äã

As the framework matured, it became clear that we needed a name that captured its fundamental nature: breaking down complexity to its most basic, powerful elements. We wanted something that embodied the idea of fundamental building blocks‚Äîthe foundation upon which everything else is constructed.

That's when we discovered the perfect fit: Preonus.

The Meaning Behind Preonus‚Äã

Preonus is a portmanteau with deep scientific and linguistic roots:

Preon ‚Äî The Ultimate Building Block‚Äã

In particle physics, preons are hypothetical subatomic, point-like particles proposed in the 1970s as the fundamental constituents of quarks and leptons. While quarks and leptons were once considered the most basic particles, preon theory suggests there might be an even deeper layer‚Äîan ultimate foundation from which everything is built.

This perfectly mirrors our framework's philosophy:

  • Fundamental ‚Äî Everything reduces to the simplest, most essential components
  • Point-like precision ‚Äî No bloat, no unnecessary abstraction
  • Building blocks ‚Äî The foundation upon which complex systems are constructed
  • Compile-time over runtime ‚Äî Resolve everything at the deepest level, before execution

Just as preons (if they exist) would be the ultimate constituents of matter, Preonus aims to be the ultimate foundation for Java applications‚Äîstripped down to pure compile-time logic with zero runtime magic.

Us ‚Äî Together in Purpose‚Äã

The suffix "us" comes from Latin, often denoting:

  • Collective unity ‚Äî A framework that brings components together
  • Belonging ‚Äî A community of developers building with the same philosophy
  • Plurality ‚Äî Many parts working as one cohesive whole

In Latin grammar, "-us" is a common noun ending that conveys substance and completeness. Combined with "Preon," it creates a name that feels both scientific and human.

The Philosophy Lives On‚Äã

At its core, Preonus is about:

  • Fundamentals first ‚Äî Build on the strongest possible foundation
  • Compile-time everything ‚Äî Resolve complexity before runtime
  • Zero magic ‚Äî Transparent, deterministic behavior
  • Maximum performance ‚Äî Remove every unnecessary layer

The name Preonus embodies this perfectly. It's a framework built on the idea that great software starts with fundamental building blocks, assembled with precision at compile time.

Join Us‚Äã

Whether you knew us as Korus or are just discovering Preonus, we're excited to have you on this journey.

The name has changed, but our mission remains: to build the fastest, most transparent Java framework‚Äîone that treats compile-time as the ultimate building block for modern applications.

Welcome to Preonus. Let's build something fundamental together.

entry.title: Switching Baseline to Java 25
entry.summary: Preonus now requires Java 25. See how we leverage the Class-File API, Compact Object Headers, and Stable Values to deliver the fastest Java framework performance yet.
entry.content:
To build the fastest dependency injection framework for the modern era, we need tools that match that ambition. Today, we are announcing that our project is moving its minimum requirement to Java 25.

While many projects still use Java 17, we found that staying on older versions forced us to use "hacks" and heavy third-party libraries that slowed down the development and performance of the framework.

Why not stay on Java 17?‚Äã

Java 17 was a great milestone, but for modern framework development, it lacks the native power available in the latest releases. Sticking to a Java 17 baseline would mean:

  • Heavy Dependencies: We would be forced to keep using external libraries like ASM or ByteBuddy for bytecode manipulation. Java 25 provides this natively.
  • More Boilerplate: Java 17 lacks the advanced Pattern Matching and Record features that make our internal code clean and high-performing.
  • Slower Startup: Java 17 doesn't support the new "Compact Object Headers" or the refined Virtual Thread stability that makes modern applications scale effortlessly.

What makes Java 25 better for this Framework?‚Äã

By switching to Java 25, we have unlocked three major "superpowers" that improve every application built with our tools:

1. The Native Class-File API‚Äã

In Java 17, reading or generating a class file required a third-party library. In Java 25, we use the Standard Class-File API. This makes our build-time processing smaller, faster, and much more stable across different environments.

2. Compact Object Headers‚Äã

Java 25 introduces Compact Object Headers, which reduce the memory footprint of every single object. For a framework that manages thousands of components, this translates to a significant reduction in heap memory usage automatically.

3. Stable Values‚Äã

We now leverage the new Stable Values API. This tells the JVM that once a dependency is injected, it will never change. This allows the JIT compiler to optimize your code as if you used static final constants, making your application run at peak hardware speed.

We are building for the next 10 years of Java, not the last 10.

entry.title: My Journey into Java and the Story Behind Preonus
entry.summary: Vinit Shinde shares his journey from learning Java to building Preonus Framework‚Äîa modern tool designed to solve the startup time and memory challenges of traditional Java.
entry.content:
Hello everyone! I‚Äôm Vinit Shinde from Pune, currently in my final year at PICT. This blog is a small part of my story as a developer and the journey that eventually led to the creation of the Preonus Java Framework.

How Everything Started‚Äã

Right after completing my 12th, I directly jumped into programming. I didn‚Äôt explore multiple languages‚ÄîI started straight with Java, and that became my world.

The biggest influence behind my entry into programming was my cousins. They guided me, motivated me, and pushed me toward Java when I didn‚Äôt even fully understand what programming actually was.

Looking back, choosing Java as my first language was one of the best decisions I‚Äôve ever made.

Growing with Java‚Äã

As I got deeper into the language, I began to explore:

  • Modern Java frameworks
  • Real-world projects
  • End-to-end development
  • Deployment pipelines

I still remember the moment when I built and deployed a complete project using a modern framework‚Äîthat‚Äôs when I felt truly confident. That‚Äôs when I realized:

"Yes, I can build real engineering systems."

Since then, I‚Äôve built over 50+ public GitHub repositories, constantly improving my skills and learning everything from the ground up.

Why I Created Preonus‚Äã

India has a massive developer ecosystem, especially around Java, but one thing always felt missing:

We didn‚Äôt have our own Java framework.

That thought stayed with me. And one day, I decided:

"If something doesn‚Äôt exist, I will build it myself."

That‚Äôs how Preonus started.

Preonus is my attempt to bring something fresh, fast, and developer-friendly to the Java world, built with a strong vision and the belief that Indian developers can create world-class open-source tools.

Vision for the Future‚Äã

My dream is simple:

In the next 5 years, Preonus should become one of the top Java frameworks in the world.

Not just another project‚Äîbut something developers love, trust, and use confidently.

This is just the beginning.

Final Words‚Äã

If you're reading this:

  • Start early
  • Learn consistently
  • Build fearlessly

You don‚Äôt need a perfect background or perfect conditions. You just need passion, discipline, and the courage to start.

Thank you for reading. This journey has shaped me as a developer, and Preonus is the biggest step of that journey. The best part is still ahead.

entry.title: Build-Time Dependency Injection Explained
entry.summary: Learn how Preonus generates dependency injection graphs at compile time, eliminating runtime reflection and proxies to deliver instant startup and minimal memory footprint.
entry.content:
Most Java frameworks use runtime DI, where objects are created and wired when the application starts.
This works ‚Äî but it's slow, unpredictable, and memory-heavy.

Preonus takes a different approach:

All dependency injection is generated at compile time.

No reflection.
No proxies.
No classpath scanning.

Why Build-Time DI?‚Äã

Build-time DI solves three major problems:

Slow Startup‚Äã

Runtime DI frameworks scan the classpath and perform reflection when the app boots.

Preonus eliminates this entirely.

Hidden Runtime Errors‚Äã

Many DI issues (circular dependencies, missing beans) are discovered only when you run the app.

Preonus validates the entire DI graph at compile time.

Large Memory Footprint‚Äã

Reflection metadata, runtime registries, proxies ‚Äî all reduce performance.

Preonus generates pure Java code instead.

How Preonus Generates the DI Graph‚Äã

During compilation, the Preonus processor:

  1. Scans your source code
  2. Builds an internal DI model
  3. Sorts beans with a topological algorithm
  4. Generates:
    • Constructor injection code
    • Method injection code
    • Singleton registries
    • Route metadata
    • A full PreonusMain bootstrap class

Everything is resolved before your application even runs.

Example Generated Code (Simplified)‚Äã

public final class UserService$$PreonusBean {
    private final UserRepository repo;

    public UserService$$PreonusBean(UserRepository repo) {
        this.repo = repo;
    }

    public UserService get() {
        return new UserService(repo);
    }
}

entry.title: Introducing Preonus Framework
entry.summary: Discover Preonus Framework: The new ultra-fast Java framework with build-time dependency injection, zero reflection, and sub-200ms startup for modern cloud-native apps.
entry.content:
Build-Time Dependency Injection for Ultra-Fast Java Applications

Preonus Framework is a modern Java framework designed around one core idea:

Move everything possible to compile time.‚Äã

Reflection, classpath scanning, proxies, and runtime bean creation all slow down traditional Java frameworks. Preonus eliminates all of them by generating:

  • Dependency wiring
  • DI registries
  • Routing metadata
  • Bootstrapping code

during compilation, not at runtime.

The result:

  • 120‚Äì250 ms startup time
  • ~50 MB memory footprint
  • Zero reflection
  • Deterministic, safe DI graph
  • Lightweight Undertow runtime

Why I Built Preonus‚Äã

While working with Spring Boot and Micronaut, I noticed a common issue:

Even build-time DI frameworks keep some runtime magic.

Some still rely on reflection, some use proxies, some still scan packages.
This inspired the architecture of Preonus:

  • Pure annotation processing
  • Pure compile-time registry generation
  • No runtime analysis
  • No surprises

Preonus aims to bring:

  • The developer experience of Spring
  • The performance of Quarkus/Micronaut
  • And a clean, minimal runtime

Architecture Overview‚Äã

Preonus consists of two independent modules:

1. Preonus Processor (Build-Time Engine)‚Äã

Responsible for:

  • Scanning source code
  • Building the DI graph
  • Performing Jandex indexing
  • Generating wiring and route registries
  • Auto-generating PreonusMain

2. Preonus Framework (Runtime Engine)‚Äã

A lightweight Undertow-based runtime that:

  • Loads pre-generated classes instantly
  • Does not use reflection
  • Does not scan the classpath
  • Boots in under 0.25 seconds

Where We Are Today‚Äã

  • 20,000+ lines of Java code
  • Two-module architecture
  • Stable build-time DI engine
  • Fast Jandex-based lookup
  • Hibernate + HikariCP integration

What‚Äôs Next?‚Äã

  • Multi-module architecture (Core, Web, Data)
  • Preonus CLI (‚Äúpreonus new app‚Äù)
  • Simpler configuration API
  • New Data access module
  • Build-time validation improvements

Preonus is now open to the Java community.
I built it to solve real problems, and I‚Äôm excited to see what developers create with it.
